1: Acciona — No major Aus M&A announced 2025-26. Large global renewables platform but limited recent deal activity in Australia.
2: AGL Australia — Part of PowAR/Tilt consortium. Defensive strategic posture; unlikely external acquirer.
3: APG — Committed US$650M to Octopus Australia (Jul 2025). Very active deployer in Aus renewables. Strong Tier 1.
4: Aula Energy — Linked to Macquarie/GIG (#64). Focus on onshore wind. MAM-backed platform.
5: BlackRock — Completed $12.5B GIP acquisition (Oct 2024). Now controls Vena Energy, Akaysha ($1B+ BESS). Dominant infrastructure platform. See also #170 GIP.
6: CDPQ (La Caisse) — Acquired Edify Energy for C$1B+ (Sep 2025). Major solar+storage platform with 11GW+ pipeline. Rebranded to 'La Caisse'. Very active.
7: CIP — Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners. Global offshore wind leader. Victoria offshore wind auctions commencing Sep 2025 may increase relevance.
8: Cobra/Vinci — See also #30 Vinci. Very interested in wind per commentary. Vinci is parent.
9: Dexus — Indicated interest in Australian asset acquisitions. Infrastructure fund pivoting to energy transition.
10: EDF — Don't do platform deals per commentary. But see #167 EDF Australia — may participate in asset-level deals.
11: EDP Renewables — Partnered with QIC on 480MWp solar + 400MW/1,600MWh BESS (Punchs Creek, QLD). Financial close expected 2026. Active.
12: Enel Green Power — Wind/BESS preference noted. See #157 Potentia Energy (Enel/INPEX JV) which acquired 1GW+ portfolio Feb 2025. Active via Potentia.
13: Engie — Won Willogoleche 2 Wind Farm tender (108MW, construction late 2026). Targeting 3GW+ Aus capacity by 2030. Active but selective.
14: FRV — OMERS acquired 49% of FRV Australia platform. 637MWDC operational, 2.7GWDC + 1.3GWh development. Well-capitalised. Active.
15: HMC Capital — Acquired Neoen Victoria portfolio for A$950M (Aug 2025): 652MW including Victorian Big Battery, Bulgana Wind Farm, Numurkah Solar. Major energy transition platform pivot. Very active.
16: Iberdrola — Commentary says not participating, BUT announced €5B Aus strategic plan 2025-28. Smithfield battery (65MW) completing end-2025, QLD battery (180MW) operational 2026. May re-engage.
17: IFM — Want a platform per commentary. Large Australian super-linked infrastructure manager. Patient capital.
18: Igneo/Atmos — Raised A$400M (Aug 2025). Portfolio now 1.5GW+ operational/construction, 5GW development. Targeting $3B deployment for 1GW+ in 2-3 years. Very active.
19: Octopus Investments — Received US$650M from APG (Jul 2025). $11B portfolio across wind/solar/BESS. Financial close on 486MWh hybrid. Very active.
20: OMERS — Acquired 49% of FRV Australia. See #14 FRV. Active through FRV platform.
21: Origin Energy — Selective M&A. Preference for larger scale and wind. Low probability for BESS until late 2026.
22: Ørsted — Secured offshore wind licences in Australia. Victoria launching first offshore wind auction Sep 2025 (2GW). Share price issues may constrain near-term M&A. Offshore wind is key angle.
23: OX2 — EQT acquired OX2 (May 2024). Secured EPBC approval for 135MW Muswellbrook solar+storage (NSW, Aug 2025). Building Aus presence. Active.
24: Palisade/Intera — Commentary says 'allocation exhausted' but completed $460M Limestone Coast BESS (Mar 2025). Now managing 2GW+ portfolio (1.7GW Aus). UPDATE COMMENTARY — still active.
25: Partners Group — Large global infra platform. No specific recent Aus renewables M&A identified.
26: RWE Innogy — Wind-focused. No major recent Aus M&A but see #186 RWE Renewables (untiered). May participate in wind opportunities.
27: SSE Renewables — UK/Ireland focused. Limited recent Aus activity.
28: Tilt Renewables — Owned by AGL/QIC/Future Fund (PowAR consortium). Want wind projects. Defensive/build rather than acquire.
29: Total/TotalEnergies — Global energy major with renewables ambitions. No specific recent Aus M&A identified.
30: Vinci — Parent of Cobra (#8). Large infrastructure group. Active in Aus via Cobra.
31: ACEN Energy — Philippines-based. Growing APAC renewables portfolio but no major Aus deals recently.
32: Amp Energy — Aus portfolio acquired by Carlyle's Revera Energy platform (2025). 750MW+ BESS, 2.3GW solar, 1.4GW wind in NEM. Now under Carlyle/Revera.
33: APA — Gas pipeline operator pivoting to renewables. Selective.
34: Aquila Capital — Indicated funding available 2026. German infrastructure manager.
35: ATCO — Interested in wind, don't like solar per commentary. Canadian utility.
36: Ausgrid — NSW distribution utility. Wind/BESS preference. Strategic but constrained by regulated asset base.
37: Banpu — Thai energy company. BESS-focused per commentary. Limited Aus M&A track record.
38: Basalt Infrastructure — US-based. No recent Aus renewable activity identified.
39: BrightNight Energy — Funding uncertain per commentary. US renewable platform.
40: Brookfield — SUGGEST UPGRADE TO TIER 1. Completed €6.1B Neoen acquisition (Apr 2025). Divested Vic assets (ACCC required) but retains massive Aus/global platform. Also controls AusNet transmission. Dominant player.
41: CanadianSolar/Recurrent — Low on excess cash per commentary. BlackRock committed $500M to Recurrent globally.
42: Capella Capital — Australian boutique. Limited public deal flow.
43: Cerberus — US PE. No specific Aus renewables activity identified.
44: ContourGlobal — UK IPP. No recent Aus M&A.
45: DGA Energy Solutions — Mitsubishi Corporation subsidiary. Japanese strategic with Aus presence.
46: DIF — Now owned by CVC. Unlikely to buy development platform per commentary. Sold Bright Energy portfolio to Potentia (Feb 2025).
47: Eku — MAM/BCI backed. Solar not in mandate. NSW appetite but constrained by technology preference.
48: Eneos — Japanese energy major. No specific recent Aus renewables M&A.
49: Energy Australia — CLP Group subsidiary. Aus retail/generation. May participate in selective M&A.
50: EPIC Energy — QIC-backed. Pipeline infrastructure. Limited renewables M&A track record.
51: EQT — Acquired OX2 (May 2024). See #23 OX2. Looking at near-term status projects. Active via OX2.
52: Federation Asset Management — Looking at NSW, pre-DA, 200MW+ minimum, wind development. Specific mandate.
53: General Electric — Equipment manufacturer. Unlikely asset buyer.
54: Glennmont Partners — Nuveen/TIAA subsidiary. European renewables focus. Limited Aus activity.
55: Goldwind — Chinese wind turbine manufacturer. FIRB risk if pursuing equity investments.
56: GPG Naturgy — Were considering divesting Aus per commentary. Potential seller, not buyer.
57: ICG — Only interested in later stage per commentary. UK PE.
58: Infrared Capital — Sun Life subsidiary. UK infra manager. Limited recent Aus renewables.
59: iSquared — Setting up platform per commentary. US infra manager.
60: Itochu — Japanese trading house. Wants majority or preference share structure. Specific requirements may limit deal flow.
61: JERA — Major Japanese power company (TEPCO/Chubu JV). Global renewables ambitions but no specific recent Aus M&A.
62: Keppel — SUGGEST UPGRADE TO TIER 1. 720MW powerbank site near Melbourne for AI/DC. Pipeline >1GW APAC. Raising capital for 2026 deployment (US$1.5B sustainable infra). Very active.
63: KKR — Not looking at developers per commentary. But owns Zenobe (#85) and John Laing (#119). May participate in operating asset deals.
64: Macquarie/GIG — May look through Aula (#4). GIG is major global renewables platform.
65: Morrison — Focusing on larger assets/portfolios. Sold NZ assets to Amber Infrastructure.

67: Northleaf Infrastructure — Canadian infra manager. No specific recent Aus activity.
68: Osaka Gas — Japanese utility. No specific recent Aus renewables M&A.
70: Petronas/Gentari — Highly active but unsuccessful to date per commentary. Interested in wind and larger assets. Malaysian sovereign-linked.
71: Quinbrook — Aus-based infra manager. Active in renewables globally.
72: RATCH — Currently selling assets per commentary. Thai utility. Potential seller not buyer.
73: SB Energy — Toyota Tsusho subsidiary. Japanese strategic.
74: SC Oscar — Fundraising but has capacity per commentary. Singapore-based.
75: Sembcorp — SUGGEST UPGRADE TO TIER 1. Acquired Alinta Energy for A$6.5B (Dec 2025). 3.4GW operational + 10.4GW pipeline + 1.1M customers. Transformational entry into Aus market. Will likely be acquiring more to fill pipeline.
76: Sojitz — Japanese trading house. No specific recent Aus renewables M&A.
77: Sosteneo — Australian infra manager. Limited public deal flow.
78: Squadron Energy — Tattarang (Forrest family). 2.4GW operating, 20GW pipeline. Secured $1B financing for Clarke Creek Wind Farm. Active but primarily self-developing.

80: Tag Energy — Portuguese developer. Limited Aus presence.
81: Tenaga Nasional — Malaysian national utility. No specific recent Aus M&A.
82: Transalta — Not looking at Aus development recently per commentary. Canadian IPP.

84: Vestas — Wind turbine manufacturer. Unlikely equity buyer.
85: Zenobe — KKR/Infracapital backed. UK BESS specialist.
86: 547 Energy — US developer. No Aus presence identified.
87: Akuo Energy — French developer. Limited Aus activity.
88: Alinta Energy — BEING ACQUIRED BY SEMBCORP ($6.5B, Dec 2025). Will no longer be independent. Remove as potential bidder or flag as Sembcorp subsidiary.
89: Apollo Management — Primarily credit-focused in Aus per commentary. May participate in structured deals.

98: CBUS — Aus super fund. Co-invested in Atmos/Igneo $400M raise (Aug 2025). Invests via managers.

159: European Energy — Danish developer. 1 operational + 9 development assets (6 QLD). Expressed interest in Windlab Lakeland. Active.

161: Amber Infrastructure — UK infra manager. Appointed Head of APAC. Acquired NZ assets from Morrison. Limited Aus renewable activity. LOW priority.

163: Bain Capital — No Aus renewable infrastructure fund or activity found. LOW priority. Consider removing.

172: Gunvor Group — Swiss commodity trader. Not a typical renewables acquirer.

175: KEPCO Australia — Partnered on 50GW WGEH project (WA). Focus is green hydrogen/ammonia export, not conventional wind/solar M&A. SUGGEST TIER 3.

177: KOMIPO — 4GW renewable for Geraldton green ammonia (WA) with Samsung. Hydrogen-focused. SUGGEST TIER 3.
